pros: The HIM staff at Rapides is very friendly and easy to work with
cons: The coding is now outsourced and is just not the same

pros: Very thorough (yet boring) hospital orientation. That was my first nursing job out of school, I was put with a very strong charge nurse as my preceptor and was given lots of support as I learned and grew in my confidence and abilities. Great teamwork between the nurses I worked with on the night shift. House supervisors were always available to help on the floor, didn't sit in an office all the time. I really respected that about them. Nurses get to do their own computerized schedules, never seen that anywhere else. Good benefits.
cons: Units didn't seem to work as well together as they could have. Each unit seemed to be like an island of their own, not looking at how their actions/timing (in reference to transfers) could affect another unit. Also, I heard from nurses on other units that the team work between the nurses isn't there on every unit..depends on which unit you're on and which group of nurses your shift falls with. Suggestions to management about possible ways of doing things better, more efficient, making nurses' jobs a little better too often fall on deaf ears. Management seems to be stuck in their ways and are not open to change, even small ones. Also, charting system is very dated and difficult to learn b/c it's not very user friendly and it's difficult to navigate.

review_title: Positive.  My employment here has been fun and flexible.
pros: Very willing to work with me in terms of scheduling around my large school load.  Management and coworkers are all very polite and liakle.
cons: Benefits are not that great.  Pay is also very poor, but pay in central Louisiana is always poor.
